case_name: Dhian Singh v. Municipal Board, Saharanpur

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 122 of 1967 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 18, 1966 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1642 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 122 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 18, 1966 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1642 of 1964.

facts.text: The accused is proprietor of Khalsa Tea Stall situated in Court Road, Saharanpur.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts relating to this appeal are these The accused in this case is proprietor of Khalsa Tea Stall situated in Court Road, Saharanpur.

facts.text: The accused was selling coloured sweets.

anchor.surface_text: Among other things, he was selling companyoured sweets.

facts.text: Food Inspector, Municipal Board, Saharanpur purchased coloured sweets from the accused for examination under a Yaddasht on May 31, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On suspicion that the sweets sold by him were adulterated, the Food Inspector, Municipal Board, Saharanpur purchased from the accused for examination some companyoured sweets under a Yaddasht on May 31, 1963

facts.text: A portion of the sweets was sent to the Public Analyst of the Government of U.P. for examination.

anchor.surface_text: and sent a portion if the same to the Public Analyst of the Government of U.P. for examination.

facts.text: Public Analyst received the sample on June 4, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: received on the 4th day of June 1963 from the Food Inspector c o Medical Officer of Health, Municipal Board, Saharanpur,

facts.text: Public Analyst submitted report on June 24, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Signed this 24th day of June 1963.

facts.text: Sample tested positive for coal-tar dye Metanil yellow, Colour Index No. 138, not permitted under rule 28 of Prevention of Food Adulteration Rules, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Test for the presence of companyl-tar dye --Positive. Coal-tar dye identified -- Metanil yellow.  companyour Index No. 138  ... companyl-tar dyes permitted for use in foodstuffs under rule No. 28 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Rules, 1955.

facts.text: Complaint filed in the court of City Magistrate, Saharanpur under s.7 read with s.16 of Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 by Municipal Board, Saharanpur, signed by Food Inspector.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of that certificate, a companyplaint was filed in the companyrt of City Magistrate, Saharanpur under s. 7 read with s. 16 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954. It is purported to have been filed by the Municipal Board, Saharanpur but it was signed by its Food Inspector.

facts.text: Accused pleaded not guilty.

anchor.surface_text: The accused pleaded number guilty.

facts.text: Trial court acquitted the accused.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt acquitted him taking the view that as the report of the analyst did number companytain any data, numberconviction companyld be rounded on its basis and as the Yaddasht relating to the sale had number been attested as required by law, the seizure in question must be held to be invalid.

facts.text: Municipal Board appealed to Allahabad High Court under s.417(3) Cr.P.C. in Criminal Appeal No. 1642 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: As against that decision, the Municipal Board of Saharanpur went up in appeal to the High Court under s. 417 3 , Cr. P.C.

facts.text: High Court allowed the appeal, convicted the accused, sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for two months and fine of Rs. 100/-, default one month imprisonment. Judgment dated April 18, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the appeal ... The judgment of the High Court was rendered on April 18, 1966. The High Court companyvicted the appellant and sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for two months. and to pay a fine of Rs. 100/-, in default to undergo further imprisonment for a period of one, month.

facts.text: No objection about maintainability of appeal taken at hearing.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the appeal, numberobjection about the maintainability of the appeal was taken.

facts.text: Accused filed application for certificate under Art. 134 on April 28, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: On April 28, 1966, the accused field an application for certificate under Art. 134 of the Constitution.

facts.text: On May 4, 1966, accused moved High Court under s.561A Cr.P.C. for review of judgment dated April 18, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: On May 4, 1966, when the application filed under Art. 134 of the Constitution for certificate was still pending, the accused moved the High Court under s. 561  A , Cr. P.C. for reviewing its judgment dated April 18, 1966

facts.text: High Court dismissed s.561A application on March 16, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The application under s. 561 A  was dismissed by the High Court as per its order of March 16, 1967

facts.text: High Court refused certificate under Art.134 on March 16, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The certificate prayed for under Art. 134 of the Constitution was also refused by a separate order of the same date.

facts.text: Appeal brought to Supreme Court after obtaining special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter this appeal was brought after obtaining special leave.

facts.text: Appellant contended that appeal by Municipal Board under s.417(3) CrPC was not maintainable as complaint instituted by Food Inspector.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Garg, learned Counsel for the appellant strenuously companytended that the appeal filed by the Municipal Board of Saharanpur before the High Court under s. 417 3 , Cr. arguments.claim: permission under s.20 PFA is condition precedent requiring sanctioning authority to apply mind to facts like in sanction cases

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Garg, learned Counsel for the accused urged that a permission under s. 20 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 to file a complaint is a condition precedent for validly instituting a complaint under the provisions of that Act.

arguments.claim: Municipal Board is local authority competent under s.20 PFA to file complaint or authorize Food Inspector

anchor.surface_text: Section 20 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 prescribes that no prosecution for an offence under that Act should be instituted except by, or with the written consent of, the Central Government or the State Government or a local authority or a person authorised in this behalf, by general or special order, by the Central Government or the State Government or a local authority. There is no dispute that the Municipal Board is a local authority.

arguments.claim: No prior objection to maintainability of complaint or appeal, parties proceeded on basis that Municipal Board was complainant

anchor.surface_text: Neither in the trial court, nor in the High Court at the stage of hearing of the appeal, any objection was taken by the accused as to the maintainability either of the complaint or of the appeal. Both those courts and the parties before it proceeded on the basis that the Municipal Board, Saharanpur was the complainant and its Food Inspector had filed the complaint on its behalf.

arguments.claim: Complaint filed by officer of local authority at its instance is in law filed by local authority (citing K.C. Aggarwal)

anchor.surface_text: In K.C. Aggarwal v. Delhi Administration, this Court has held that a complaint filed by one of the officers of a local authority, at the instance of that authority is in law a complaint instituted by that local authority.

arguments.claim: Official acts presumed regular; authority of Food Inspector not challenged earlier cannot be raised post-appeal

anchor.surface_text: Official acts must be deemed to have been done according to law. If the accused had challenged the authority of the Food Inspector to file the complaint, the trial court would have gone into that question.

arguments.claim: Under s.20 PFA no need to apply mind to specific facts; general authority conferred beforehand; distinguishes sanction cases
report of analyst contains data on basis of which conclusion reached
High Court had no power to review its own judgment under s.561A CrPC

anchor.surface_text: The application under s. 561 A  was dismissed by the High Court as per its order of March 16, 1967 repelling the contention of the accused that the complaint had not been instituted by the Municipal Board. It further came to the conclusion that it had no power to review its own judgment.

holdings.text: The appeal filed by the Municipal Board, Saharanpur before the High Court of Allahabad under s. 417(3) of the Criminal Procedure Code was maintainable in law as the complaint was instituted by the Municipal Board through its authorised Food Inspector.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Municipal Board is local authority under s.20 PFA competent to institute prosecution or authorise Food Inspector; complaint purports to be by Board; no prior objection raised; presumption of official regularity; precedent in K.C. Aggarwal applies.

holdings.text: A complaint filed by an officer of a local authority at its instance is in law a complaint instituted by that local authority.

anchor.surface_text: In K.C. Aggarwal v. Delhi Administration, this Court has held that a complaint filed by one of the officers of a local authority, at the instance of that authority is in law a complaint instituted by that local authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Supreme Court precedent in K.C. Aggarwal v. Delhi Administration.

holdings.text: Permission under s.20 PFA does not require the sanctioning authority to apply its mind to the facts of the particular case; general or special order suffices.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes from sanction cases requiring case-specific consideration (Gokulchand, Madan Mohan); s.20 confers general authority beforehand for prosecutions.

holdings.text: Accused cannot raise objection to authority of Food Inspector or maintainability of complaint/appeal for the first time after disposal of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Neither in the trial court, nor in the High Court at the stage of hearing of the appeal, any objection was taken by the accused as to the maintainability either of the complaint or of the appeal. Both those courts and the parties before it proceeded on the basis that the Municipal Board, Saharanpur was the complainant and its Food Inspector had filed the complaint on its behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prior challenge; parties proceeded on validity; presumption official acts regular; question of fact not raised earlier; analogy to Mangaldas Raghavji on sanctions.

holdings.text: The accused could be convicted on the strength of the certificate of the Public Analyst as it contains the necessary data on which the conclusion was based.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Report identifies coal-tar dye Metanil yellow (not permitted under Rule 28), provides analytical data (butyro-refractometer, melting point, etc.); directly contradicts claim of lacking data.

holdings.text: The High Court had no power to review its own judgment under s.561A Cr.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: The application under s. 561 A was dismissed by the High Court as per its order of March 16, 1967 repelling the contention of the accused that the complaint had not been instituted by the Municipal Board. It further came to the conclusion that it had no power to review its own judgment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly concluded lack of review power; noted without further analysis by SC.

anchor.surface_text: K.C. Aggarwal v. Delhi Administration 1 , this Court has held that a companyplaint filed by one of the officers of a local authority, at the instance of that authority is in law a companyplaint institut- Criminal Appeal No. 100 of 1966 decided on 27th May, 1969 ed by that local authority.

precedents.cited_proposition: a complaint filed by one of the officers of a local authority, at the instance of that authority is in law a complaint instituted by that local authority

precedents.citation: Mangaldas Raghavji and Anr. v. State of Maharashtra and Anr. 1

anchor.surface_text: Mangaldas Raghavji and Anr. v. State of Maharashtra and Anr. 1 Mr. Garg, learned Counsel for the accused urged that a permission under s. 20 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 to file a companyplaint is a companydition precedent for validly instituting a companyplaint under the provisions of that Act.

precedents.case_name: Mangaldas Raghavji and Anr. v. State of Maharashtra and Anr.
precedents.cited_proposition: refused to entertain for the first time an objection as regards the validity of a sanction granted

precedents.citation: Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King 2

anchor.surface_text: Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King 2 and Madan Mohan Singh v. The State of U.P. 3 . Both those decisions deal with the question of the validity of sanctions given for the institution of certain criminal proceedings. The provisions under which sanction was sought in those cases required the sanctioning authority to apply its mind and find out whether there was any justification for instituting the prosecutions.

precedents.case_name: Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King
precedents.cited_proposition: in cases of sanction, the court must be satisfied that all the relevant facts had been placed before the sanctioning authority and that authority had granted the sanction after applying its mind to those facts

precedents.citation: Madan Mohan Singh v. The State of U.P. 3
precedents.case_name: Madan Mohan Singh v. The State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: in cases of sanction, the court must be satisfied that all the relevant facts had been placed before the sanctioning authority and that authority had granted the sanction after applying its mind to those facts

anchor.surface_text: Neither in the trial court, nor in the High Court at the stage of hearing of the appeal, any objection was taken by the accused as to the maintainability either of the complaint or of the appeal. Both those courts and the parties before it proceeded on the basis that the Municipal Board, Saharanpur was the complainant and its Food Inspector had filed the complaint on its behalf.

For the reasons mentioned above, we are unable to accept the companytention of the accused that the Municipal Board of Saharanpur was number companypetent to file the appeal. The only other question canvassed before us is that the report of the analyst companyld number have afforded a valid basis for rounding the companyviction as the data on the basis of which the analyst had reached his companyclusion is number found in that report or otherwise made available to the companyrt. We are unable to accept this companytention as well. It is number companyrect to. say that the report does number companytain the data on the basis of which the analyst came to his companyclusion.

The application under s. 561 A was dismissed by the High Court as per its order of March 16, 1967 repelling the contention of the accused that the complaint had not been instituted by the Municipal Board. It further came to the conclusion that it had no power to review its own judgment.
